headline: O'Reilly raises annual profit view as tariffs spur DIY auto repairs
summary: (Reuters) -Auto-parts distributor O'Reilly Automotive raised its annual profit forecast on Wednesday, as President Donald Trump's tariffs push cost-conscious consumers to choose replacement parts over new vehicles.  The company now expects its full-year profit to be in a range of $42.90 to $43.40 per share, from $42.60 to $43.10 per share previously.  It also reiterated its 2025 revenue estimates, expecting to record between $17.4 billion to $17.7 billion.

It also reiterated its 2025 revenue estimates, expecting to record between $17.4 billion to $17.7 billion.

headline: Compared to Estimates, O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) Q1 Earnings: A Look at Key Metrics
summary: While the top- and bottom-line numbers for O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) give a sense of how the business performed in the quarter ended March 2025, it could be worth looking at how some of its key metrics compare to Wall Street estimates and year-ago values.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) Misses Q1 Earnings and Revenue Estimates
summary: O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) delivered earnings and revenue surprises of -4.88% and 0.80%, respectively, for the quarter ended March 2025. Do the numbers hold clues to what lies ahead for the stock?

summary: ORLY) on Wednesday reported first-quarter net income of $538.5 million. On a per-share basis, the Springfield, Missouri-based company said it had net income of $9.35. The results missed Wall Street expectations.

headline: O'Reilly (NASDAQ:ORLY) Misses Q1 Revenue Estimates
summary: Auto parts and accessories retailer O’Reilly Automotive (NASDAQ:ORLY) fell short of the market’s revenue expectations in Q1 CY2025 as sales rose 4% year on year to $4.14 billion. The company’s full-year revenue guidance of $17.55 billion at the midpoint came in 0.6% below analysts’ estimates. Its GAAP profit of $9.35 per share was 5.6% below analysts’ consensus estimates.
